summary: Build an e-commerce marketplace app similar to Meesho/Amazon, and support packaging the website into a mobile app.
architectural_notes: Deployment/app domain names must be 5–50 characters and contain only letters, numbers, and hyphens.
User confirmed they want a Play Store–style mobile app package (Android wrapper/WebView) built from the existing website/PWA.
User confirmed they want to move the current build toward a Play Store–ready version (Android wrapper/TWA/WebView packaging path).
User requested help making an APK of the app (Android packaging/build output).
User confirmed they want the APK download link generated (proceed with APK build/output and hosting instructions).
APK downloads must serve a real .apk file from the /apk-download flow (correct filename/path) so Android recognizes it as an APK, not a generic document.
User requested converting the Android build into an AAB (Android App Bundle) for Google Play Store publishing; Play Store submission requires AAB (not APK).
AAB download links must serve a real .aab file from the /downloads path (the file must be present on the server) so the Google Play Console upload works.
User confirmed they want the AAB download link generated for app draft Version 18.
User requested generating an APK download link for draft/production Version 20.
known_issues: User reports the downloaded file is being treated as a 'docs' format instead of an .apk (likely incorrect link/filename or missing APK asset at the download URL).
User reports the provided AAB download link (https://strager.icp0.io/downloads/app-release.aab) does not work (likely missing asset / not uploaded).
AAB build process encountered an 'AI service error' during rebuild attempts.
User reports the Version 26 APK direct download link (https://strager.icp0.io/downloads/strager-marketplace-v26.apk) is not working (likely missing asset/404 or incorrect hosting path).
User reports the UI currently shows the name “Amazon” (unwanted third-party branding) and it should not appear anywhere in the app.

existing_features.title: Implement Internet Identity sign-in/sign-out and show authentication state across the app (e.g., header shows Sign in / Account).

Build the buyer browsing experience: home page with featured sections, category browsing, product grid listing, search and basic filters (category + price range), and product detail page with add-to-cart.
Implement cart and checkout flow: cart page with quantity updates/removal, order summary, and a checkout form (shipping address fields) that creates an order in the backend (no external payments).
Add account area with order history and order details for the signed-in buyer.

Add a minimal seller flow: a 'Seller Dashboard' where a signed-in user can create, edit, and deactivate their own product listings (including selecting from predefined categories and choosing from provided static images).

Create a coherent, distinctive visual theme for the marketplace UI (colors, typography, spacing, and component styling) and apply it consistently across pages (header, navigation, cards, buttons, forms). Avoid blue/purple as primary colors.
Add static generated images under frontend/public/assets/generated and use them in the UI (logo, hero banner, and category icons).
Generate a new static app icon image featuring a single capital letter "S" and add it to the project under frontend/public/assets/generated.
Update the web app HTML to reference the new "S" icon as the site favicon (and apple-touch-icon if applicable) using the static asset path.
Ensure the generated app icon image file exists at frontend/public/assets/generated/app-icon-s.dim_512x512.png and is served correctly as a static asset.
Add Progressive Web App (PWA) support so the existing website can be installed on Android/iOS as an app (home screen / app launcher), using a Web App Manifest and the existing static app icon assets.

Register a service worker to enable offline-capable app-shell behavior for the PWA (cache core static assets and show a simple offline fallback for navigation requests when the network is unavailable).

Add a simple in-app guidance screen (or modal) with English instructions explaining how to install the app on Android (Chrome) and iPhone (Safari), accessible from the UI (e.g., footer link or header menu).
Ensure the Strager web app works as an installable PWA on Android (Chrome) and iOS (Safari), with the correct app icon, manifest metadata, install guidance route, and offline fallback behavior.

Ensure the Strager PWA/app icon and favicon reliably update after deployments by forcing clients to pick up the latest cached icon assets (e.g., update the service worker cache versioning/cleanup strategy so stale icon assets are not served).

Add an English troubleshooting note to the in-app installation guidance explaining what to do if the installed app icon or favicon does not update (e.g., hard refresh/clear site data/uninstall & reinstall the PWA), with steps for Android (Chrome) and iPhone (Safari).

Add a new user-accessible page that explains, in English, how to convert the existing Strager website into a publishable mobile app using an Android/iOS wrapper approach (as distinct from the existing PWA install instructions). The page must clearly present: (1) PWA install option (already supported), (2) Android wrapper app option suitable for Google Play (e.g., Trusted Web Activity or WebView wrapper), and (3) iOS wrapper app option suitable for the App Store (e.g., WKWebView wrapper).

Expose navigation to the new 'mobile app packaging' guidance page from the existing UI so users can find it easily (at minimum from the existing Install App area, and optionally from the header or footer).

On the wrapper-app packaging guidance page, document (in English) the exact app icon and PWA metadata assets already present in the project so the user knows what to reuse for store listings (e.g., manifest icon files under /assets/generated and the site name/short name).
Add a user-accessible Privacy Policy page with English text suitable for Play Store submission, and make it reachable from the main UI (at minimum via the global footer).
Add a user-accessible Terms of Service page with English text, and make it reachable from the main UI (at minimum via the global footer).
Add a user-accessible Support/Contact page in English that can be used as the Play Store ‘support URL’, and make it reachable from the main UI (at minimum via the global footer).

Extend the existing ‘Package as Mobile App’ guidance page to include a Play Store submission checklist section that references the app’s in-site Privacy Policy URL, Terms URL, and Support URL (all English) and calls out the need for store screenshots and feature graphic assets.

Add a static Digital Asset Links file at frontend/public/.well-known/assetlinks.json for Android Trusted Web Activity (TWA) support, with clearly marked placeholders and English comments/instructions for replacing values during Play Store packaging.

Generate Play Store listing marketing images (feature graphic + at least 4 phone screenshots) as static assets under frontend/public/assets/generated, then reference them in the PWA manifest screenshots array and ensure the service worker precaches them (or otherwise guarantees they are available offline once cached).

When adding new store-listing assets and updating the manifest, increment the cache-busting versioning consistently across frontend/index.html, frontend/public/manifest.webmanifest, and frontend/public/sw.js so clients pick up the updated manifest/icons/assets after deployment.

Add a user-accessible “Play Store Listing Info” section (either on the existing /mobile-app-packaging page or as a clearly linked sub-section within it) that provides copy/paste-ready Play Store metadata in English, including: app name, short description, full description, app category, content rating note (high-level), and the exact in-app URLs for Privacy Policy, Terms, and Support pages.

Improve Android Trusted Web Activity (TWA) readiness guidance by making the placeholder values in frontend/public/.well-known/assetlinks.json unmistakable and adding an adjacent plain-text instruction file (e.g., frontend/public/.well-known/assetlinks.README.txt) that explains, in English, exactly what values must be replaced (package name and SHA-256 certificate fingerprint) and where to obtain them.

Add a final “Pre-submission Checklist” section to the existing mobile app packaging guidance that confirms the current PWA manifest/service worker cache-busting version values are aligned (the ?v=… values in frontend/index.html and frontend/public/manifest.webmanifest, and CACHE_VERSION in frontend/public/sw.js) and provides a single English instruction: increment them together on each release.

Update the Play Store metadata URLs shown on the /mobile-app-packaging page to use the current deployed site origin instead of placeholder domains, so the copied URLs are correct for the active deployment.

Ensure the /mobile-app-packaging page styling remains consistent with the app’s non-blue/purple visual theme by removing or replacing blue-accented UI styling used specifically in the “Play Store Listing Info” section.
Harden the “Copy” interactions on the /mobile-app-packaging page so they fail gracefully when the Clipboard API is unavailable or blocked, using English user-facing feedback.

Update the existing “Package as Mobile App” guide page to include an explicit, step-by-step section focused on producing an installable Android APK for testing (and an AAB for Play Store), written in English and tailored to this Strager deployment URL shown on the page.

Add a “Trusted Web Activity (TWA) prerequisite” subsection in the Android wrapper guidance that points users to the existing Digital Asset Links files in the repo and explains, in English, that they must replace placeholders before TWA verification will work.
Ensure the “Install Strager App” page includes a clear callout that users who specifically want an APK for installation/testing should follow the “Package as Mobile App” guide (English text).

Add a new user-accessible route/page at /apk-download that explains (in English) how to make a locally-built Android APK available for download, including: where to place the APK in the repo as a static asset, what URL it will be served from after deployment, how users can install it on Android (enable ‘Install unknown apps’), and basic safety notes (verify filename, version, and source).

Expose navigation to the new /apk-download page from existing mobile-app guidance UX, by adding a prominent link/button on the “Package as Mobile App” page and adding a footer link labeled “Download APK”.

Add a repo-local static downloads folder and documentation for APK hosting by creating frontend/public/downloads/README.txt (English) that explains what file to place there (e.g., app-release.apk), recommended naming conventions, and how to update/replace the file between releases without confusing users.

Update the existing /apk-download page to generate and display a direct, copyable APK download URL (based on the current site origin) and provide a prominent “Download APK” button that links to that URL.
Allow the /apk-download page’s APK filename to be set without code changes by supporting a URL parameter for the filename (e.g., a query string), and ensure the generated link updates accordingly.
Update the developer-facing instructions (including the downloads folder README) to reference the new “direct download link” behavior and the supported filename parameter, using English text.

Update the /apk-download page to proactively detect when the generated direct APK URL does not point to a real APK file (e.g., missing file/404 or unexpected Content-Type) and show a clear English error state that explains the likely cause (APK not uploaded to frontend/public/downloads/ or filename mismatch) and how to fix it.

Add a shareable “APK Download Page Link” section on /apk-download that generates and displays a copyable URL to the page itself using the current site origin and the active filename parameter (e.g., /apk-download?filename=...); include an English hint that sharing this page link is safer than sharing an unverified direct file link.

Update the existing “Package as Mobile App” guide page to include an explicit, step-by-step section focused on producing a Play Store–ready Android App Bundle (AAB), written in English, including a clear statement that an APK cannot be directly converted into an AAB and that you must rebuild the wrapper project to generate an AAB.

Update developer-facing static download documentation to clearly distinguish APK vs AAB usage: keep APK hosting instructions for direct installation, and add an English note that AAB files are for Play Store upload (not direct install) and therefore are not meant to be distributed via the /downloads/ APK link flow.

Add a new user-accessible page at route /aab-download that generates a direct Android App Bundle (AAB) download URL based on the current site origin and a filename query parameter, similar to the existing /apk-download behavior.
Implement AAB URL validation on /aab-download so the UI clearly explains when the generated AAB link does not work because the file is missing or is serving the wrong content type.
Expose navigation to /aab-download from the existing UI so users can find the AAB link generator easily.

Add developer-facing documentation in the repo explaining how to make an AAB file available at a working URL under /downloads/, emphasizing that the AAB is for Play Console upload (not direct installation).

Update the /aab-download page so that when no ?filename=... query parameter is provided, it defaults to a Version 17 AAB filename (use a versioned default like app-release-v17.aab) instead of the unversioned app-release.aab.
Update developer-facing download documentation to use Version 17 as the example for AAB hosting/link generation so the guidance matches the new default AAB filename shown on /aab-download.
Update the /aab-download page so that when no filename query parameter is provided, it defaults to a Version 18 AAB filename (app-release-v18.aab) instead of app-release-v17.aab.
Update all user-facing text on the /aab-download page that references the 'current default' AAB version so it consistently reflects Version 18 (v18) and app-release-v18.aab.

Update developer-facing static download documentation under frontend/public/downloads/README.txt so the documented current default AAB filename matches Version 18 (app-release-v18.aab) and all example default links align with v18.

Update the /aab-download page so that when no ?filename=... query parameter is provided, it defaults to a Version 19 AAB filename (app-release-v19.aab) instead of app-release-v18.aab, so the page generates the correct AAB download link by default.
Update all user-facing text on the /aab-download page that references the current default AAB version/filename so it consistently reflects Version 19 (v19) and app-release-v19.aab.

Update developer-facing static download documentation at frontend/public/downloads/README.txt so the documented current default AAB filename matches Version 19 (app-release-v19.aab) and all example default links align with v19.

Update the /apk-download page so that when no ?filename=... query parameter is provided, it defaults to a Version 20 APK filename (use a versioned default like strager-marketplace-v20.apk) instead of the current default strager-marketplace-v1.apk.

Update developer-facing documentation in frontend/public/downloads/README.txt to reflect the current default APK filename used by /apk-download (Version 20), and ensure all example APK links and filenames align with that default.

Update the /apk-download page so that when no ?filename=... query parameter is provided it defaults to the Version 21 APK filename strager-marketplace-v21.apk (instead of the current default strager-marketplace-v20.apk), so the page generates the correct Version 21 APK download link by default.

Update all user-visible examples and developer guidance on the /apk-download page that hardcode the previous default APK filename so they consistently reference Version 21 (strager-marketplace-v21.apk) as the example/default where applicable.

Update developer-facing documentation at frontend/public/downloads/README.txt so the documented current default APK filename matches Version 21 (strager-marketplace-v21.apk) and all example default links align with v21.

Update the /aab-download page so that when no ?filename=... query parameter is provided it defaults to the latest release AAB filename for Version 22 (use a versioned default like app-release-v22.aab instead of the current default app-release-v19.aab), so the page generates the correct latest AAB download link by default.

Update developer-facing static download documentation at frontend/public/downloads/README.txt so the documented current default AAB filename matches Version 22 (app-release-v22.aab) and all example default links align with v22.
Update app/site metadata and user-visible branding so it no longer hardcodes “Marketplace” where the user expects “Home”, including header logo alt text and footer copyright text.

Ensure the app’s URL/origin is not hardcoded in any user-facing guidance or link generation logic; all generated URLs must be based on the runtime site origin (window.location.origin) with a sensible SSR fallback and no placeholder domains shown to users.
Add a visible “Home” entry in the header navigation that routes to “/”, and ensure it is the primary/default top-level destination replacing any “Marketplace” concept in navigation.

Create a right-aligned “Settings” entry in the header (desktop and mobile) that opens a right-side menu/panel containing all “settings/help/legal/download” links currently scattered in the UI (e.g., Install App, App Store Guide, Download APK, Download AAB, Privacy Policy, Terms, Support).

Update PWA/app metadata to reflect the updated branding (Home vs Marketplace) where applicable, without changing routing behavior: update the manifest name/description if they currently emphasize “Marketplace” in a way that conflicts with the new “Home” navigation label.
Update the Settings menu to open from the left side of the screen (left-side sheet/panel) so that all Settings items appear in a left-side menu instead of the current right-side panel.

Hide the “App Installation” section (and its links such as “Install App”, “App Store Guide”, “Download APK”, “Download AAB”) for users who are currently in the “profile creation/setup required” state (i.e., authenticated but caller user profile is not created yet). The “Legal & Support” section must remain visible.

Make the Profile setup (first-time profile creation) UI and copy more professional and consistent with the app branding by removing “Marketplace” phrasing and using clearer, more formal English microcopy and labels.

Make the first-time Profile setup (profile creation dialog) more professional and consistent with Strager branding by updating English microcopy/labels and improving the dialog’s layout/typography while keeping the same required fields and behavior.

Update the mobile header layout to match the structure shown in the uploaded screenshot: a compact top bar (menu button + Strager logo), followed by a full-width search bar with a prominent right-side search action, and quick access actions for Account (sign-in/profile) and Cart with item count.

Add a mobile-only secondary navigation row under the search bar that displays three quick links similar to the screenshot (e.g., “Shop by Category”, “Deals”, “Sell”), with sensible routing within the existing app.

Update the Home page layout to include a delivery/location info strip under the header (as shown in the screenshot), using a simple non-GPS UI (no real location detection) with an “Update location” affordance.

Replace the current Home page hero section with a mobile-first promotional banner carousel similar to the uploaded screenshot (large rounded promo cards with bold headline text), and keep it responsive for desktop.
Add a Home page quick-benefits row under the promo area, showing 3–4 compact icon+label items similar to the screenshot (e.g., “Free Delivery”, “Secure Payments”, “Coupons”, “Easy Returns”).

Ensure the updated layout integrates cleanly with existing pages and navigation: the header remains sticky, does not overlap content, and does not break desktop navigation already present in the existing Header component.
Add the required new static promo/banner images under frontend/public/assets/generated and wire them into the new Home page promo carousel.
Remove the third-party brand name “Amazon” from the mobile header search UI and replace it with Strager-appropriate, generic English placeholder text.

Audit the frontend for any remaining occurrences of third-party marketplace branding (e.g., “Amazon”, “amazon”, “Amazon.in”) in user-facing text and remove/replace them with Strager branding or neutral English copy.

Add a clearly labeled “Buy” entry point in the main navigation so users can easily access the shopping/browsing experience (route to /products), and ensure it is visible for both authenticated and unauthenticated users on desktop and mobile.

new_feature_requests.summary: Create an e-commerce marketplace app similar to Meesho/Amazon (shopping/marketplace app).
Create backend data models and APIs for an e-commerce marketplace: products, categories, product images (as URLs to frontend static assets), carts, orders, and user profiles (buyer/seller basics).
Create an app icon featuring the letter 'S' for the app (to use for APK/Play Store packaging).
Confirm frontend/index.html references /assets/generated/app-icon-s.dim_512x512.png for both the favicon and apple-touch-icon, and that browsers display the new icon after a hard refresh.
Help convert/package the existing website into a mobile app (e.g., Android/iOS wrapper or PWA installable app) so the site can be used as an app.
Prepare the current build for Google Play Store submission (Play Store–ready Android packaging/build and submission readiness).
Build an Android APK for the current Strager web app (Android wrapper/TWA/WebView packaging) so it can be installed/tested.
Convert/package the Strager Android build into a Play Store–ready AAB (Android App Bundle) for upload to Google Play Console.
Generate an APK download link for Strager draft/production Version 21.
Generate an AAB download link for the latest Strager release (Version 22).
Add a seller commission/earning model: apply 5% commission on each seller sale (admin earning) with net payout to seller.
Change/update the site and app URL (deployment/app origin/domain) to a new URL requested by the user.
Update the app navigation so the 'Home' tab shows instead of 'Marketplace' (replace/rename default tab to Home).
Hide the “Installation/Install App” section for users who are creating/editing their profile (do not show install guidance in the profile creation flow).
Make the Profile section more professional (improve layout/typography/content presentation of the profile area).
Move all Settings to the left side of the app UI (left-aligned / left-side menu or panel) instead of right-side.
Ensure the top navigation uses “Home” as the primary label and does not show “Marketplace” where a user expects “Home” in the header navigation experience.
Ensure the header navigation uses “Home” as the primary label (instead of any “Marketplace” wording) across both desktop and mobile navigation entries, and routes to “/”.

Move the Settings menu sheet/panel to open from the left side of the screen on both desktop and mobile, and keep Settings as a single consolidated entry point for installation, guidance, download, legal, and support links.

Hide the “App Installation” section (and its links such as “Install App”, “App Store Guide”, “Download APK”, “Download AAB”) for users who are authenticated but have not completed initial profile creation yet; the “Legal & Support” section must remain visible in Settings.
Generate a working APK download link for Strager Version 26 (and ensure the APK file is actually available under /downloads).
Remove any third-party app names/branding (e.g., “Amazon”) from Strager UI/copy and ensure only Strager branding appears throughout the app.
